content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature and the long duration of the game, I would opt for strategy R, {R}. The strategy of always picking R guarantees a profit of 45$ per round if the opponent also picks R. However, since I am comfortable with taking risks, even though there is a possibility of earning 0$ in some rounds, I believe that over 75 rounds, my overall earnings would be higher compared to consistently choosing B, where the maximum possible profit per round is only 42$. Moreover, by choosing R, I increase the chances of my opponent switching strategies and picking R as well, potentially leading to more profitable rounds.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Given my previous choice of R, I will stick with that strategy for the next round as well, {R}. In this situation, choosing R ensures that I don't incur any losses, while my opponent benefits from our disagreement. However, I believe that over a long series of rounds, my riskier strategy may still prove to be more profitable due to the higher payout when both players choose R. This time, there is a chance that my opponent will switch strategies and pick R in response to my choice, leading to a more advantageous situation for me.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent chose B in the previous round, I will switch strategies for this round and choose B, {B}. By switching to B now, there's a chance that my opponent will pick R in response, resulting in a profit of 42$ for me. If my opponent continues with their strategy of always choosing B, I will still be able to earn a steady 12$ per round, which is not as attractive as the potential profits from picking R but remains a guaranteed income.

In the long run, it's difficult to predict whether sticking with R or switching to B will result in a higher overall profit. However, by alternating strategies, I can potentially capitalize on my opponent's tendency to stick with their previous choice and take advantage of the higher payouts when they do switch. The unpredictability of this game makes it even more intriguing, as both players must consider the possible strategies of their opponents in addition to their own.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both my opponent and I have chosen B in the previous round, resulting in a payout of 12$ for both players. For the next round, I will stick with my choice of B, {B}. Since my opponent and I are both earning the same amount from our choice, it is less likely that they will switch strategies in response to my choice this time. However, I must remain vigilant and be ready to adapt if the situation changes in subsequent rounds.

By consistently choosing B, I guarantee a steady income of 12$ per round. This strategy may not provide the highest possible profit, but it ensures that I don't incur any losses and earn a reasonable return over the long run. In this game, the unpredictability of the opponent's strategies and the potential for higher payouts when we both choose R make it essential to remain flexible and adaptable in my decision-making process.
